questions.question: What is the chemical composition of STAM-17-OEt?
questions.answer: Cu(C10O5H8)Â·1.6H2O

questions.question: What method was used to synthesize STAM-17-OEt?
questions.answer: Hydrothermal methods

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of MOFs that leads to potential applications as storage and delivery materials?
questions.answer: Extremely high porosity and surface area

questions.question: Why does STAM-17-OEt exhibit better hydrolytic stability compared to HKUST-1?
questions.answer: Due to the presence of weak, sacrificial bonds in the material that act as 'crumple zones' to protect the structure from water damage.

questions.question: What happens to STAM-17-OEt when it is exposed to moisture?
questions.answer: It retains its structural integrity even after contact with water for one year.

questions.question: What is the main drawback of MOFs according to the text?
questions.answer: Their relatively low stability, especially when challenged with reactive adsorbates such as water.

questions.question: True or False: The adsorption of toxic gases from breathable air for personal protection is an example where the porosity of MOFs lends itself to real-world applications.
questions.answer: True

questions.question: True or False: Changing the chemical composition of the MOF itself is the only way to increase its stability.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What is the role of 'sacrificial' bonds in the coordination environment of metal centres in MOFs?
questions.answer: They endow a dehydrated copper-based MOF with good hydrolytic stability by breaking upon exposure to water, allowing the framework to recover its as-synthesized, hydrated structure.

questions.question: True or False: STAM-17-OEt undergoes significant structural changes upon dehydration that are observable in 13C solid-state NMR spectra.
questions.answer: True

questions.question: What is the main reason for the improved stability of STAM-17-OEt compared to HKUST-1?
questions.answer: The crumple zone mechanism that directs energy from water adsorption away from critical bonding, protecting the structure.

questions.question: True or False: The electronic properties of the linker in the MOF structure are the major reason for the improved hydrolytic stability of STAM-17-OEt.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What happens to the mass of STAM-17-OEt when exposed to a moist environment at 298 K?
questions.answer: It shows an initial rapid increase in mass as the dehydrated material adsorbs water, then no further change.

questions.question: True or False: The adsorption capacity of HKUST-1 for ammonia decreases immediately upon exposure to moisture.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What is the effect of changing the 5-substituent on the isophthalate linker from ethoxy to methylcarboxy (-CO2Me) on the MOF's stability?
questions.answer: The MOF behaves in the same way as STAM-17-OEt, showing that the electronic properties of the linker are not the major reason for improved stability.

questions.question: True or False: The presence of weak, sacrificial bonds in STAM-17-OEt is the only factor contributing to its improved hydrolytic stability.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of hemilabile MOFs?
questions.answer: They allow the possibility of the formation of new weak bonds on removal of the coordinated water molecules, maintaining structural integrity as water is readsorbed.

questions.question: True or False: The adsorption of water on STAM-17-OEt leads to the indiscriminate breaking of metal-linker framework bonds.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What is the main goal of recent research in improving the stability of MOFs?
questions.answer: Increasing the stability of MOFs by changing the chemical composition or using post-synthetic modifications.

questions.question: True or False: The flexibility of MOFs, such as that which occurs in materials like MIL-53, involves bond breaking or rearrangement.
questions.answer: False
